div.head: 4.11.1882 Samstag
div.p: Ball at the Schröders. Went to the hairdresser to have my hair arranged a little. He pomatomed, and washed, and cosmetiqued it till I might have used it instead of an umbrella, and then rubbed it with a very ill looking and smelling towel. Aunt Lulu came to fetch me when I was dressed and off I went to the Schröders. As soon as I got there I was introduced to and asked to dance with a whole row of girls, with awful names, in the right sense of the word, who were sitting around the room bolt upright not saying a word, and I was very glad to find some old aquaintances. Asher was there, looking rather more skeletonly, if such a thing is possible, than ever, did not know a soul, did not want to know a soul, didn’t want to dance (because he was afraid of breaking his shirt front); the truth is that he could not find anybody to dance with him on account of his looks: everybody called him the bat, and one of his most marvellous feats was his serving of the cream with his fingers. I danced a good deal with Belle Haspberg, who is very nice; but the prettiest girls there were the Busse’s Alice, Berta, Frieda, Lilly und Mary who looked sweet. I took Belle to dinner and after dinner, as the piano player had gone away, one of us began playing; but it was impossible to dance to this music, and so little idea had the boy of how a waltz ought to be played that he went off into a polka; in trying to dance to this beautiful potpoury I distinguished myself by sprawling down with the little Schröder. And after this feat I went away after a very pleasant evening. I drove to aunt Lulu’s, to sleep there, so as not to keep the Blümers Auguste u. Wilhelm up the whole night. Aunt Lulu was still up; and I went to bed in her stranger’s-room.
